responses.content: Azure's growth is fueled by multiple factors. Firstly, cloud migrations continue to accelerate, especially with the recent announcement that Oracle databases are now available on Azure. This has unlocked new customers with significant Oracle estates looking to consolidate their cloud infrastructure. Secondly, we're seeing a continuous cycle of workload optimization and new workload starts, particularly in AI-driven projects. Our leadership in AI has led to numerous new project initiations, enhancing our Azure utilization and driving further adoption.

Our approach to AI integration is comprehensive, leveraging a full-stack strategy that ensures high utilization and optimization of our infrastructure. By maintaining a single large model for both training and inference across all our first-party SaaS applications and Azure AI Services, we achieve significant scale leverage. This strategy not only enhances revenue generation but also optimizes our capital expenditures, ensuring that our AI investments are sustainable and impactful.

The pace of innovation at Microsoft remains strong, with new products gaining traction faster than anticipated. Our focus on delivering high-value solutions ensures that we can sustain commercial growth even in a volatile spending environment. The early adoption and positive feedback from our customers give us confidence in the continued demand for our innovative offerings.

We are committed to driving operating leverage and margin improvements by strategically allocating resources to high-growth and differentiated areas. Our operating expenses have been kept in line with headcount growth and strategic investments, ensuring efficiency and scalability.

Azure's seasonality has diminished as our consumption continues to grow consistently, particularly in high-growth and premium SKUs. Operating expenses are expected to align with headcount growth, and our gross margins benefit from a shift towards higher-margin services.

Despite ongoing supply chain challenges, our Windows OEM segment exceeded guidance thanks to strong demand in the commercial sector. Higher revenue per license in this segment has contributed to robust performance in both Q1 and Q2.

Our large enterprise commitments are driven by the comprehensive scope of our Microsoft Cloud offerings, including Dynamics 365, Power Platform, Microsoft 365, and Azure. These commitments reflect strong renewals, high recapture rates, and increased add-ons across our product suite.

Our cash flow is projected to grow in tandem with operating income, supported by strong sales, improving margins in the cloud segment, and effective business execution. We remain focused on optimizing for customer success and maintaining financial health.

Inflationary pressures are being mitigated by productivity gains from digital transformation initiatives. Our investments in high-growth areas and stringent operational controls ensure that we maintain strong gross margins and operational efficiency.

questions: Based on the new products and innovation, do you think you can sustain the type of commercial growth that we saw in Q1 as we go through the year, or is the environment too tricky for that?

Regarding investment, you've been able to keep overall OpEx growth very low this quarter. At some point, should we be thinking about a return to a more aggressive investment behind all this product innovation?

AI has been far stronger than expected, beating your guidance for Azure this quarter. Has the fact that Microsoft has a full AI dev stack, copilot reference architecture, and plug-in architecture been a meaningful factor, not just from a revenue perspective, but also potentially from a margin perspective?
Can you give us any color on whether Azure GPUs are predominantly used for model training, or are we seeing a lot of inferencing yet from clients?
Congrats on the 28% constant currency Azure growth. What is your outlook for Azure in the second half of the fiscal year, especially considering the increasing AI contributions and GPU capacity?
With Office 365 Commercial seat growth in the double-digit range, how do you see the future growth potential given Microsoft's dominant market position?

The Intelligent Cloud segment operating margins are at their highest level in six years, despite elevated AI investments. Is this due to a one-time tailwind, or has Azure reached a scale where high margins are sustainable even with ambitious AI investment cycles?

Microsoft Cloud gross margins have improved by two points year-over-year, excluding the useful life change. Do you foresee continued gross margin improvement over the medium term, even as higher capex from AI investments filters into the model?
